maml:description.maml:para: Gets the Teredo configuration of a computer or a Group Policy Object (GPO).
The Get-NetTeredoConfiguration cmdlet gets the Teredo configuration of a computer or a Group Policy Object (GPO).

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the Group Policy session from which to get the Teredo configuration information.
You can use this parameter with the NetGPO cmdlets to aggregate multiple operations performed on a GPO.
You cannot use this parameter with the PolicyStore parameter.
Specifies the interface for which to get the Teredo configuration. If the interface is not a Teredo interface, then the cmdlet does not return any Teredo configuration information.

Specifies the policy store from which to retrieve the configuration. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- PersistentStore
-- ActiveStore
-- GPO
The default value is ActiveStore.
To retrieve the configuration from a GPO, specify the GPO name using the following format: Domain\GPOName
You cannot use this parameter with the GPOSession parameter.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the Group Policy session from which to get the Teredo configuration information.
You can use this parameter with the NetGPO cmdlets to aggregate multiple operations performed on a GPO.
You cannot use this parameter with the PolicyStore parameter.
Specifies the interface for which to get the Teredo configuration. If the interface is not a Teredo interface, then the cmdlet does not return any Teredo configuration information.

Specifies the policy store from which to retrieve the configuration. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- PersistentStore
-- ActiveStore
-- GPO
The default value is ActiveStore.
To retrieve the configuration from a GPO, specify the GPO name using the following format: Domain\GPOName
You cannot use this parameter with the GPOSession parameter.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
This cmdlet accepts no input objects.

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.
This cmdlet returns a Teredo configuration object.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get the Teredo configuration of a computer

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the Teredo configuration from the active store on the local computer.

maml:description.maml:para: Resets the Teredo configuration elements in a Group Policy Object (GPO).

The Reset-NetTeredoConfiguration cmdlet resets the Teredo configuration elements in a Group Policy Object (GPO) configurations to the not configured state. Group Policy settings have three possible states: not configured, enabled, and disabled.
If used with no parameters, this cmdlet resets all Teredo configurations on the specified store.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Resets the UDP port of the client to not configured.
Resets the Teredo qualification configuration to false. This parameter can only be specified on GPOs.

Specifies the Group Policy session that contains the Teredo configuration to reset.
You can use this parameter with the NetGPO cmdlets to aggregate multiple operations performed on a GPO.
You cannot use this parameter with the PolicyStore parameter.
Specifies the interface on which to reset the Teredo configuration. If the interface specified is not a Teredo interface, then the cmdlet does not return any configuration.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the policy store that contains the Teredo configuration to reset. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- PersistentStore
-- ActiveStore
-- GPO
To reset the configuration of a GPO, specify the GPO name using the following format: Domain\GPOName
You cannot use this parameter with the GPOSession parameter.
Resets the client refresh interval to 30 (seconds).
Resets the server name to teredo.ipv6.contoso.com.
Resets the server shunt configuration to False.
Resets the IPv4 address of the Teredo configuration to 0.0.0.0.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Resets the type of the Teredo configuration to default.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Resets the UDP port of the client to not configured.
Resets the Teredo qualification configuration to false. This parameter can only be specified on GPOs.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Resets the client refresh interval to 30 (seconds).
Resets the server name to teredo.ipv6.contoso.com.
Resets the server shunt configuration to False.
Resets the IPv4 address of the Teredo configuration to 0.0.0.0.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Resets the type of the Teredo configuration to default.
Specifies the object which contains the Teredo configuration information to reset.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Resets the UDP port of the client to not configured.
Resets the Teredo qualification configuration to false. This parameter can only be specified on GPOs.

Specifies the Group Policy session that contains the Teredo configuration to reset.
You can use this parameter with the NetGPO cmdlets to aggregate multiple operations performed on a GPO.
You cannot use this parameter with the PolicyStore parameter.
Specifies the object which contains the Teredo configuration information to reset.
Specifies the interface on which to reset the Teredo configuration. If the interface specified is not a Teredo interface, then the cmdlet does not return any configuration.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the policy store that contains the Teredo configuration to reset. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- PersistentStore
-- ActiveStore
-- GPO
To reset the configuration of a GPO, specify the GPO name using the following format: Domain\GPOName
You cannot use this parameter with the GPOSession parameter.
Resets the client refresh interval to 30 (seconds).
Resets the server name to teredo.ipv6.contoso.com.
Resets the server shunt configuration to False.
Resets the IPv4 address of the Teredo configuration to 0.0.0.0.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Resets the type of the Teredo configuration to default.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
This cmdlet accepts no input objects.

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.
When the Passthru parameter is specified, this cmdlet outputs a modified Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command resets the Teredo configuration to the not configured state.

maml:description.maml:para: Modifies the Teredo configuration of a computer or a Group Policy object (GPO).
The Set-NetTeredoConfiguration cmdlet modifies the Teredo configuration of either a computer or a Group Policy Object (GPO).

Specifies the state of Teredo. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- Disabled: Disables the Teredo service.
-- Client: Enables the Teredo client.
-- Enterpriseclient: Skips the managed network detection.
-- Server: Enables the Teredo server.
-- Default: The default state is client.
Specifies the name or IPv4 address of the Teredo server.
Specifies the client refresh interval in seconds.
Specifies the UDP port of the client computer. If this parameter is not specified, then the port is chosen by the operating system.
Specifies the virtual IPv4 address of the server. This parameter is not applicable if the computer is a Teredo client. This parameter can only be specified on GPOs.
Determines if this cmdlet qualifies Teredo by default. The default value is False. This parameter can only be specified on GPOs.
Indicates that the tunnel miniport and IPv4 routing layer are bypassed for high throughput on the Teredo relay functionality of the Teredo server.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the Group Policy session to which to store the configuration information.
You can use this parameter with the NetGPO cmdlets to aggregate multiple operations performed on a GPO.
You cannot use this parameter with the PolicyStore parameter.
Specifies the interface on which to set the Teredo configuration. If the specified interface is not a Teredo interface, then the cmdlet does not return any configuration.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the policy store that contains the configuration to set. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- PersistentStore
-- GPO
The default value is PersistentStore.
To set the configuration of a GPO, specify the GPO name using the following format: Domain\GPOName
You cannot use this parameter with the GPOSession parameter.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Specifies the state of Teredo. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- Disabled: Disables the Teredo service.
-- Client: Enables the Teredo client.
-- Enterpriseclient: Skips the managed network detection.
-- Server: Enables the Teredo server.
-- Default: The default state is client.
Specifies the name or IPv4 address of the Teredo server.
Specifies the client refresh interval in seconds.
Specifies the UDP port of the client computer. If this parameter is not specified, then the port is chosen by the operating system.
Specifies the virtual IPv4 address of the server. This parameter is not applicable if the computer is a Teredo client. This parameter can only be specified on GPOs.
Determines if this cmdlet qualifies Teredo by default. The default value is False. This parameter can only be specified on GPOs.
Indicates that the tunnel miniport and IPv4 routing layer are bypassed for high throughput on the Teredo relay functionality of the Teredo server.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the object which contains the Teredo configuration information to modify.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the UDP port of the client computer. If this parameter is not specified, then the port is chosen by the operating system.
Determines if this cmdlet qualifies Teredo by default. The default value is False. This parameter can only be specified on GPOs.

Specifies the Group Policy session to which to store the configuration information.
You can use this parameter with the NetGPO cmdlets to aggregate multiple operations performed on a GPO.
You cannot use this parameter with the PolicyStore parameter.
Specifies the object which contains the Teredo configuration information to modify.
Specifies the interface on which to set the Teredo configuration. If the specified interface is not a Teredo interface, then the cmdlet does not return any configuration.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the policy store that contains the configuration to set. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- PersistentStore
-- GPO
The default value is PersistentStore.
To set the configuration of a GPO, specify the GPO name using the following format: Domain\GPOName
You cannot use this parameter with the GPOSession parameter.
Specifies the client refresh interval in seconds.
Specifies the name or IPv4 address of the Teredo server.
Indicates that the tunnel miniport and IPv4 routing layer are bypassed for high throughput on the Teredo relay functionality of the Teredo server.
Specifies the virtual IPv4 address of the server. This parameter is not applicable if the computer is a Teredo client. This parameter can only be specified on GPOs.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

Specifies the state of Teredo. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- Disabled: Disables the Teredo service.
-- Client: Enables the Teredo client.
-- Enterpriseclient: Skips the managed network detection.
-- Server: Enables the Teredo server.
-- Default: The default state is client.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

This cmdlet accepts no input objects.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Set the Teredo server name

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command sets the Teredo server name to Test on the local persistent store.
This command sets the Teredo state to enterpriseclient in a GPO named Domain\GPOname.
